intro: Bourreria setosohispida, commonly known as the hairy bristly morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the Americas. It belongs to the Convolvulaceae family and is characterized by its twining stems and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. It thrives in tropical and subtropical regions, often growing along fences or in disturbed soils. Its hairy leaves and bristly stems are notable features that aid in its identification.
